data.title: Merged Phillipe Rollin's (@prollin) RenderTarget changes for Android
data.body: Also Using the new GraphicsCapabilities properties for Depth24 and DepthNonLinear, use those to Set the right Depthformat when calling GL.RenderbufferStorage() inside GetTextureData.

data.title: Effect file corrupted when parsing to MGFX
Updating PR 1498
data.body: Updating PR 1498 with a new NextPOT and fix on the condition trigger to resize the bitmap rendering buffer.

data.title: [WinDX] Stretch/missing pixels issue
data.body:
So I have two computers
- development machine (desktop - Win7 64-bit)
- other machine (laptop Win8 64-bit)

When I tested my game so far on my laptop the result was concerning. Some pixels rendered differently which started making me worry. (the game is completely 2D).

It seems like if I try to stretch out 1 pixel from a spritesheet and draw it beyond a certain x width/y height, there are a row of pixels that are not drawn and are left out even though the rectangle bounds specified are supposed to cover this left out area. However this does not happen on my desktop which is why it confuses me.

I begin drawing with:

engine.spriteBatch.Begin(SpriteSortMode.Deferred, null, SamplerState.PointClamp, null, null);

Some example of code which creates the issue:

engine.spriteBatch.Draw(engine.textures.interfaceWindow, new Rectangle(0, 0, engine.display.width, engine.display.height), new Rectangle(16, 49, 1, 1), Color.White, 0f, Vector2.Zero, SpriteEffects.None, 0f);
- engine.textures.interfaceWindow - is just the basic texture
- new Rectangle(0, 0, engine.display.width, engine.display.height) - creates the target bounds to draw to be the whole window
- new Rectangle(16, 49, 1, 1) - only gets one source pixel from the interfaceWindow spritesheet (this is just the back color of a window, using it in this way just for the example).

On my desktop, the above code colors the whole screen correctly with one color. On my laptop, it will draw over almost all of the screen but the right and bottom edges, the edges are not touched and nothing is drawn (there is a white outline 1 pixel in width at the edges of the rendering scene). This small "untouched" gap gets larger the bigger I make the target rectangle.

Images:
On my desktop:
![hmmm2](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3013922/445288/a24493c8-b1b8-11e2-9a6e-15ebe55fc0f3.png)

On my laptop:
![hmmm](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/3013922/445304/07632d14-b1b9-11e2-9c56-6396ab8d5d7a.png)

Thats just the top right of the window, the bottom of the window also has the white line. Also notice that the "untouched" gap there is larger than 1 pixel, this is because I had a large render width, making the target Rectangle's width larger.

I had trouble explaining this, I thoroughly looked at my code and I just cannot see how this can be a problem I am making myself.

I'm about to go to sleep so I may not reply for some time, thanks for reading.

data.title: Added missing Content folder to newest windows platforms.
data.body: Miss Content folder when creating project on newest windows platforms (win8,win8 xaml,windows phone)? This should fix this.

data.title: Monogame not working on Windows with mono
data.body:
Hi, I am using Xamarin studio to create windows game. I am also using F# as base language. First issue I have faced as I have add manual library of monogame windows but I guess that is Xamarin issue.

Now, main issue I have faced that it is not working with mono 3.0.7, I need to run with .Net runtime only. Now, Xamarin has open issue if I am running with .Net Framework I can't run in debug, I have to run without debug only. 

Please let me know if am missing something here?

Also let me know if more information required.

data.title: Touch issues on Windows Phone - getting NaN for touch points
data.body:
Another very strange issue which I've yet to get to the bottom of.

I have two (almost identical) solutions running in MonoGame on Windows Phone, both use the TouchPanel in the same way and also use Gestures as well.

in one the touch coordinates are reported correctly.  However in the other they are returned as NaN (or wildly inaccurate by the millions).
There is practially no differentiation between these projects except one works and one doesn't

Any ideas?

data.title: Performance issues on Windows Phone
data.body:
Got stonewalled by some performance issues with the release & code builds on the Windows Phone platform this weekend.

The shocked sample on my blog works fine on pretty much all platforms extremely well except for Windows Phone???

In the release build the app actually crashes with a memory overflow
In the code build it runs but for the first 10 - 20 seconds perf is terrible, it improves after that but is nowhere near as efficient as the other platforms (including native Silver XNA solution on WP7).

Any ideas or suggestions?

data.title: Windows Store game crashes at startup
data.body:
I'm working on porting a game from XNA to MonoGame.  It compiles, but when I try to run the game crashes underneath the splash screen.  I can step through the code in Main() and the constructor for my game class runs, but after leaving the constructor for the game class, it crashes and I see this message in the output:

A first chance exception of type 'System.TypeLoadException' occurred in MonoGame.Framework.Windows8.DLL

I can't get any more info about the exception, I tried wrapping a try/catch around the code in Main() but the code in catch is never reached.

Also, I can make a blank MonoGame Windows Store project and run it just fine.

data.title: Fixed default values for MediaQueue ActiveSongIndex
data.body: In XNA the activeSongIndex property defaults to -1. This was not the case so I have updated the code to take this into account. Also fixed a bug where calling MediaPlayer.Play was not setting the activeSongIndex when playing a single song. We got away with this before because the index defaulted to 0.

data.title: iOS Guide.IsVisible not set to false when closing keyboard
data.body: When you call Guide.EndShowKeyboardInput () on iOS it never sets Guide.IsVisible to false, so if you're using (!Guide.IsVisible) to determine whether to display the keyboard, it won't open again after closing it the first time.  Looking at the Android version, IsVisible is set to false in the finally { } block.

data.title: DxtBitmapContent and PackedVector additions
data.body:
Added bitmap content classes for DXT1,3,5.
DxtBitmapContent is now abstract.
Removed DxtBitmapContent.TryGetFormat (implemented by derived classes).
Added Bgr565, Bgra4444, Byte4 packed vector classes to all projects.
Corrected case for DxtBitmapContent, PvrtcBitmapContent.
DxtBitmapContent now matches XNA and C# naming conventions.
PvrtcBitmapContent follows suit.
ExternalReference relativeToContent now works properly.

data.title: Fix so that FullScreen works correctly on SoftKey Android devices.
data.body: Should work with Gingerbread and above. Thanks Matthieu Laban (Infinite Flight) for pointing it out.

data.title: Added support for all remaining SurfaceFormat values in OpenGL
data.body:
Adds support for HalfVector2, HalfVector4, Rg32, Rgba64, Rgba1010102, Vector2, Vector4, HdrBlendable, NormalizedByte2, NormalizedByte4.

Supported for OpenGL, not OpenGL ES 2.0.

data.title: AndroidGameActivity memory leaks
data.body:
There are memoy leaks in AndroidGameActivity. AndroidGamePlatform subscribes to static events AndroidGameActivity.Paused and AndroidGameActivity.Resumed. These handlers are not unsubscribed when destroying activity.

When pressing back button and entering application again it will create another Game class but previous instances are never garbage collected because of these static events.

Tested in Getac Z710, Android 2.3.5, Mono for Android 4.6.02.

data.title: Simplified WP8 trial mode
data.body:
Simplified WP8 trial mode because the Windows 8 style license information is error-prone.
The license is often found to be invalid after tombstoning.

data.title: Incorrect Viewport placement
MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Builder.PipelineProcessorContext does not implement BuildAndLoadAsset
data.body:
Or, rather, it just throws `NotImplementedException`.

I use `BuildAndLoadAsset` within my custom content pipeline, so this is preventing me from switching my content over to monogame.

data.title: Custom Types in Custom Content Projects - Should it be supported?
data.body:
This is a bit of an edge case scenario that I came across while testing some XNA samples.

The CustomModelClass Sample uses a custom type that is only defined in the client solution (not in XNA).  It's also defined in the custom content pipeline solution as a custom type.

This is all laid out in the XNA Custom Model class sample here:
http://xbox.create.msdn.com/en-US/education/catalog/sample/custom_model_class

What this gives is a way to tag custom or compiled data within the processed content model as a custom type.

Should this be a use case MonoGame supports.

P.S.
It would need the host solution to pass it's assembly name to MonoGame for reference as "getCallingAssembly" is gone in WinRT / Win8 (not sure about others yet)

data.title: Fix for Content/ContentTypeReaderManager.cs to allow type resolution from calling project.
data.body:
Whilst creating a starter kit to test custom content pipeline use and serialisation/deserialisation (from the MS CustomModelClass Sample) I encountered an issue where types from the calling project (custom types) could not be de-serialised through Monogame.  This was simply because the ContentTypeReaderManager could only resolve from the MonoGame project alone

This fix allows custom types in projects to be resolved in content reader type resolution from a client solution

Will also post the StarterKit demonstrating its use

data.title: SoundEffectInstance Volume is not updated.
data.body:
On Android I discovered that SoundEffectInstances are not updating the volume of sound after the Play() has been called. The solution to this is to fix the setter for Volume property in SoundEffectInstance and apply the changed volume.

While I was searching for solution to this I also discovered that SoundEffects and SoundEffectInstance share the same Sound, which carries information about volume pan and loop. In case where we set instance to be looped the SoundEffect will also be looped. I think that this should be somehow fixed.

data.title: Added a method to cancel BeginShowKeyboardInput.
Getting a "Wrong MGFX version" on startup, any ideas?
data.body:
When I step through I note that the "version" that comes out of the BinaryReader is version 3 and the reader checks this version against a preset value which is 5.

So the incompatibility is obvious from a code example.

What i'm wondering is why and how to resolve this, guessing there is something in the effect file and the way it's compiled is wrong???

data.title: Windows Starter Kits & samples don't function
data.body:
Not sure if this is worth looking at but probably more problematic for new devs looking into Monogame.

None of the starter kits function for one of the two reasons below
- They rely on Texture2D.FromStream which in directX throws a "Not Implemented" exception
- Missing references to "AudioEngine", "Cue", "Soundbank", "WaveBank"

I suspect the above is probably the projects not being updated with recent changes but without altering default exceptions in VS, they won't even tell you this and just crash.

Similar issues exist with the Samples for Windows as you cannot even open the Windows Solution as it complains that the particle project isn't supported (in both VS2010 / VS2012)  and numerous other build errors.

These either need fixing or replacing going forward in line with @CartBlanche 's suggestion of new samples.

For the newbie it doesn't look especially good in the repo right now. (plus no WindowsGL / Windows 8 versions)

data.title: Adds the default constructor for TouchCollection.
data.body: Without this constructor the TouchCollection class, since is a struct and don't need to be instantiated, can throw some exceptions when you call, for example, the Count method. This assures full XNA compatibility.

data.title: Adds the default constructor for TouchCollection.
data.body: Without this constructor the TouchCollection class, since is a struct and don't need to be instantiated, can throw some exceptions when you call, for example, the Count method. This assures full XNA compatibility.

data.title: [WinDX] Fullscreen
data.body: Fullscreen mode not yet implemented on the Windows DirectX platform.

data.title: Follow XDG Spec and Application Data on Mac/Linux.
data.body:
Currently MonoGame will dump a "SavedGames" folder in the Home folder on Linux and Mac (sometimes `~/Documents/`?), if the game uses the StorageDevice.

This does not obey the specification of either OS, and the SavedGames folder is not particularly useful like it is on Windows.

For Linux, we follow the XDG specification, where user savedata goes in XDG_DATA_HOME, which is `~/.local/share/` by default.

For OSX, we use `~/Library/Application Support/` by default.

So, for instance, if your game name is "VigilantePsychologist", your Linux saves will be in `~/.local/share/VigilantePsychologist/`, and your OSX saves will be in `~/Library/Applcation Support/VigilantePsychologist/`.

There is a fallback in place, but by the time we reach those fallbacks, it's expected that the OS running this game is just about screwed. Not all distros specify an XDG_DATA_HOME, but every *nix should provide a HOME.

data.title: Rectangle class is missing Serializable attribute
data.body: Looking at the Vector classes there should be a DataContract attribute as well (in WinRT)
